summary: Internal email correspondence among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing disparities in discovery and counsel access between Ghislaine Maxwell and Justin Rivera, two detained defendants. The emails detail the government's planned response to a judicial inquiry about differing accommodations, attributing them to case specifics, housing situations, and facility logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused co-conspirator in the Epstein case, detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in protective custody, receiving extensive discovery and counsel access accommodations.

persons.name: Justin Rivera
persons.context: Defendant in a separate sex trafficking conspiracy case, detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in general population, with lesser accommodations for discovery and counsel access compared to Maxwell.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge in United States v. Rivera et al., who raised concerns about disparities in access between Maxwell and Rivera and requested an explanatory declaration from the BOP.

persons.name: Bhaskaran
persons.context: AUSA in the Southern District of New York who authored the initial email bringing the disparity issue to colleagues' attention.

connections.description: Both are federal detainees whose accommodations for discovery review and attorney access are being compared by the court, with Maxwell receiving significantly more access.
Judge Engelmayer is presiding over Rivera's case and has expressed frustration with the MCC's treatment of Rivera, ordering accommodations and requesting explanations for disparities.

events.title: Disparity Issue Raised
events.description: AUSA Bhaskaran emails colleagues to alert them about Judge Engelmayer's concerns regarding disparities in counsel and discovery access between Maxwell and Rivera.

events.title: Draft Response Finalized
events.description: SDNY staff circulate drafts of a letter and declaration explaining the rationale for differing accommodations between Maxwell and Rivera, attributing it to housing, case size, and facility logistics.

events.title: Declaration Due
events.description: Deadline for the government to submit a declaration from the BOP to Judge Engelmayer explaining why accommodations for Maxwell cannot be extended to Rivera.

events.title: Scheduled Trial for Rivera
events.description: Rivera's trial in his sex trafficking conspiracy case is expected to start on this date.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was housed in protective custody at the MDC with sole access to a room for computer/phone use ~13 hours/day, while Justin Rivera was in general population at the MCC sharing a VTC room with ~80 other inmates.
Maxwell's case involved 'multiple times more discovery' than Rivera's, justifying greater electronic access needs.
The MCC began leaving a laptop with Rivera all day for charging, effectively matching Maxwell's electronic discovery access, but VTC access remained limited to avoid compromising other inmates.
Judge Engelmayer described the disparity in access as 'strikingly different' with 'terrible' optics, and defense counsel suggested differential treatment based on race, gender, and class.
The government's explanation centered on specific circumstances: case discovery volume, attorney requests, and individual housing situations at different facilities (MDC vs. MCC).
